content.text:
# Timeline of the 1993 Atlantic hurricane season

The 1993 Atlantic hurricane season consisted of the events that occurred in the annual cycle of tropical cyclone formation over the Atlantic Ocean north of the Equator. The official bounds of each Atlantic hurricane season are dates that conventionally delineate the period each year during which tropical cyclones tend to form in the basin according to the National Hurricane Center, beginning on June 1 and ending on November 30. However, tropical cyclogenesis is possible at any time of the year, as evidenced by the development of Tropical Depression One on May 31, one day before the official start of the season. By contrast, the dissipation of Tropical Depression Ten on September 30 effectively concluded the season two months before it officially ended. September 21 was the final date on which a system of at least tropical storm strength was active; this was described in a 1995 retrospective from Monthly Weather Review as the earliest such occurrence since 1930.|group="nb"}} Seasonal activity was below average – of the season's 10 tropical depressions, eight strengthened further to become named tropical storms and four became hurricanes, compared to contemporary long-term averages of 10 tropical storms and six hurricanes, and modern averages of 14 tropical storms and seven hurricanes. Hurricane Emily was the only Atlantic major hurricane in 1993; this is slightly below the contemporary average of two major hurricanes per season, while modern seasons produce three on average.
The two most impactful systems of the season were Tropical Storm Bret and Hurricane Gert; more than 300 people were killed by the combined effects of both storms. Bret became a catastrophic storm for Venezuela after extreme rainfall triggered widespread flooding and mudslides in the Caracas area, causing significant impacts in Nicaragua as well; the latter country would suffer renewed flooding from Gert just over a month later. After hitting Nicaragua, Gert—a sprawling and moisture-laden tropical cyclone—generated heavy rainfall over a large portion of Central America and Mexico. Several other tropical cyclones caused extensive flooding during the season. Tropical Depression One and the precursor to Tropical Storm Arlene each killed 20 people, the former in Cuba and Haiti, and the latter due to a single mudslide in El Salvador. After becoming a tropical cyclone, Arlene caused considerable flood damage in South Texas and northeastern Mexico. In August, Tropical Storm Cindy produced more than a foot (12 in; 30.48 cm) of rain in Martinique. At the end of the month, the western eyewall of Hurricane Emily passed over the Outer Banks of North Carolina while the storm was near its peak intensity; powerful winds and record-breaking floods caused three fatalities and heavy but localized damage.
By convention, meteorologists use one time zone, Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), when issuing forecasts and making observations; they also use the 24-hour clock, where 00:00 = midnight UTC. The National Hurricane Center uses both UTC and the time zone where the center of the tropical cyclone is presently located. Prior to 2020, three time zones were utilized in forecast products for Atlantic tropical cyclones: Atlantic, Eastern, and Central, from east to west.
In this timeline, all information is listed by UTC first, with the respective regional time zone included in parentheses. Additionally, figures for maximum sustained winds and position estimates are rounded to the nearest five units (knots, miles, or kilometers) and averaged over one minute, following National Hurricane Center practice. Direct wind observations are rounded to the nearest whole number. Atmospheric pressures are listed to the nearest millibar and nearest hundredth of an inch of mercury. This timeline documents tropical cyclone formations, strengthening, weakening, landfalls, extratropical transitions, and dissipations during the season. It includes information that was not released throughout the season, meaning that data from post-storm reviews by the National Hurricane Center has been included.
Timeline of events
May
May 31
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. EDT) at Tropical Depression One forms from an interaction between a tropical wave and a monsoonal gyre about 60 mi (95 km) west of the Isle of Youth. Later in the day, the system traverses central Cuba.
June
June 1
*The 1993 Atlantic hurricane season officially begins.
*00:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. EDT, May 31) at Tropical Depression One emerges over the Straits of Florida about 65 mi (100 km) east of Varadero, Cuba.
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. EDT) at Tropical Depression One reaches maximum sustained winds of 35 mph (55 km/h) and a minimum barometric pressure of  about 290 mi (465 km) northeast of Varadero, Cuba.
June 2
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. EDT) at Tropical Depression One transitions into an extratropical cyclone, strengthening to gale force as it does so, about 795 mi (1,280 km) east-northeast of Varadero, Cuba.
June 18
*00:00 UTC (7:00 p.m. CDT, June 17) at Tropical Depression Two forms from an area of disturbed weather over the Bay of Campeche.
June 19
*12:00 UTC (7:00 a.m. CDT) at Tropical Depression Two develops a new center of circulation as the old center dissipates about 115 mi (185 km) to the southeast. The overall system strengthens into Tropical Storm Arlene about 155 mi (250 km) southeast of Corpus Christi, Texas; it simultaneously reaches maximum sustained winds of 40 mph (65 km/h) and a minimum barometric pressure of .
June 20
*09:00 UTC (4:00 a.m. CDT) at Tropical Storm Arlene makes landfall over Padre Island, Texas, with sustained winds of 40 mph (65 km/h) and a barometric pressure of .
*12:00 UTC (7:00 a.m. CDT) at Tropical Storm Arlene weakens into a tropical depression about 45 mi (75 km) southwest of Corpus Christi, Texas.
June 21
*06:00 UTC (1:00 a.m. CDT) at Tropical Depression Arlene is last noted as a tropical cyclone about 70 mi (110 km) southwest of Corpus Christi, Texas; it degenerates into a remnant low six hours later.
July
*No tropical cyclones were active in July.
August
August 4
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. AST) at A tropical depression forms from a tropical wave about 1,115 mi (1,855 km) west-southwest of Cape Verde.
August 5
*00:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. AST, August 4) at The tropical depression strengthens into Tropical Storm Bret about 1,215 mi (1,955 km) east of Trinidad.
August 6
*06:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Bret reaches maximum sustained winds of 60 mph (95 km/h) about 570 mi (915 km) east of Trinidad.
August 7
*00:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. AST, August 6) at Tropical Storm Bret reaches a minimum barometric pressure of  about 185 mi (295 km) east of Trinidad.
*07:00 UTC (3:00 a.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Bret makes landfall near Galera Point in northern Trinidad with sustained winds of 60 mph (95 km/h) and a barometric pressure of .
*10:00 UTC (6:00 a.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Bret makes landfall near Macuro, Venezuela, with sustained winds of 60 mph (95 km/h) and a barometric pressure of . It reemerges over water ten hours later, remaining close to the northern coast of Venezuela.
August 8
*08:00 UTC (4:00 a.m. EDT) at Tropical Storm Bret makes landfall near Chichiriviche, Venezuela, with sustained winds of 45 mph (75 km/h) and a barometric pressure of .
August 9
*06:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. EDT) at Tropical Storm Bret emerges over the southwestern Caribbean Sea.
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. EDT) at Tropical Storm Bret weakens into a tropical depression about 410 mi (660 km) east of Punta Gorda, Nicaragua.
August 10
*06:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. EDT) at Tropical Depression Bret restrengthens into a tropical storm about 165 mi (270 km) east of Punta Gorda, Nicaragua.
*12:00 UTC (7:00 a.m. CDT) at Tropical Storm Bret reaches its secondary peak intensity about 85 mi (140 km) east-southeast of Punta Gorda, Nicaragua, with sustained winds of 45 mph (75 km/h) and a barometric pressure of .
*17:00 UTC (12:00 p.m. CDT) at Tropical Storm Bret makes landfall about 30 mi (45 km) south of Punta Gorda, Nicaragua, at its secondary peak intensity.
August 11
*00:00 UTC (7:00 p.m. CDT, August 10) at Tropical Storm Bret weakens back into a tropical depression inland about 80 mi (130 km) west of Punta Gorda, Nicaragua. The remnants of Bret regenerated into a tropical cyclone on August 15, which became Hurricane Greg of the 1993 Pacific hurricane season.|group="nb"}}
August 14
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. AST) at A tropical depression forms from a tropical wave about 110 mi (175 km) east-southeast of Martinique.
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at The tropical depression strengthens into Tropical Storm Cindy as it makes landfall on Martinique with sustained winds of 40 mph (65 km/h) and a barometric pressure of .
August 16
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Cindy reaches maximum sustained winds of 45 mph (75 km/h) and a minimum barometric pressure of  about 85 mi (140 km) southeast of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic.
*21:00 UTC (5:00 p.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Cindy weakens into a tropical depression as it makes landfall near Barahona, Dominican Republic, with sustained winds of 35 mph (55 km/h) and a barometric pressure of .
August 17
*00:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. AST, August 16) at Tropical Depression Cindy is last noted as a tropical cyclone inland about 45 mi north-northwest of Barahona, Dominican Republic; it dissipates shortly thereafter.
August 22
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at A tropical depression forms from a tropical wave about 915 mi (1,475 km) east-northeast of Puerto Rico.
August 23
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. AST) at Another tropical depression forms from an area of disturbed weather well to the west of the coast of Africa.
August 24
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. AST) at The tropical depression west of Africa strengthens into Tropical Storm Dennis.
August 25
*06:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Dennis reaches maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 km/h) and a minimum barometric pressure of .
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. AST) at The tropical depression that had formed far to the east-northeast of Puerto Rico three days prior strengthens into Tropical Storm Emily about 775 mi (1,250 km) north-northeast of that island.
August 26
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Emily strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 675 mi (1,085 km) north-northeast of Puerto Rico. The system's sustained winds simultaneously reach an initial peak of 75 mph (120 km/h); its barometric pressure is  at this time.
August 27
*00:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. AST, August 26) at Hurricane Emily weakens into a tropical storm about 640 mi (1,030 km) north-northeast of Puerto Rico, though the system's barometric pressure decreases to  and continues to drop over the next 48 hours.
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Dennis weakens into a tropical depression.
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Emily restrengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 580 mi (935 km) north-northeast of Puerto Rico.
August 28
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. AST) at Tropical Depression Dennis dissipates.
August 29
*00:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. EDT, August 28) at The barometric pressure of Hurricane Emily reaches an initial minimum of  about 625 mi (1,010 km) southeast of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina.
August 31
*06:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. EDT) at Hurricane Emily strengthens to Category 2 intensity about 190 mi (305 km) south-southeast of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina.
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. EDT) at Hurricane Emily strengthens to Category 3 intensity about 50 mi (85 km) south-southeast of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, making it the only major hurricane of the season; it simultaneously reaches maximum sustained winds of 115 mph (185 km/h).
*21:00 UTC (5:00 p.m. EDT) at Hurricane Emily makes its closest approach to Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, passing about 25 mi (35 km) to the east with sustained winds of 115 mph (185 km/h) and a barometric pressure of .
September
September 1
*00:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. EDT, August 31) at Hurricane Emily reaches a minimum barometric pressure of  about 45 mi (75 km) northeast of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina.
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. EDT) at Hurricane Emily weakens to Category 2 intensity about 225 mi (360 km) northeast of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina.
September 3
*00:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. AST, September 2) at Hurricane Emily weakens to Category 1 intensity about 910 mi (1,465 km) east-northeast of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina.
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at Hurricane Emily weakens into a tropical storm about 1,015 mi (1,630 km) east of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina.
September 4
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Emily weakens into a tropical depression about 1,030 mi (1,660 km) east of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina.
September 6
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. AST) at Tropical Depression Emily transitions into an extratropical cyclone about 1,460 mi (2,355 km) east-northeast of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina.
September 7
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. EDT) at A tropical depression forms from a tropical wave about 485 mi (780 km) north-northwest of the Virgin Islands.
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. EDT) at The tropical depression strengthens into Tropical Storm Floyd about 470 mi (760 km) south-southwest of Bermuda.
September 8
*00:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. EDT, September 7) at Tropical Storm Floyd reaches its initial peak intensity with sustained winds of 50 mph (85 km/h) and a barometric pressure of .
September 9
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Floyd strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 735 mi (1,185 km) north-northeast of Bermuda; it simultaneously reaches its peak intensity as a tropical cyclone, with maximum sustained winds of 75 mph (120 km/h) and a minimum barometric pressure of .
September 10
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at Hurricane Floyd transitions into an extratropical cyclone about 1,750 mi (2,815 km) northeast of Bermuda.
September 14
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. EDT) at A tropical depression forms from a tropical wave about 105 mi (165 km) north of the Caribbean coast of Panama.
September 15
*12:00 UTC (7:00 a.m. CDT) at The tropical depression strengthens into Tropical Storm Gert about 70 mi (110 km) southeast of Bluefields, Nicaragua.
*18:00 UTC (1:00 p.m. CDT) at Tropical Storm Gert makes landfall near Bluefields, Nicaragua, with sustained winds of 40 mph (65 km/h) and a barometric pressure of .
September 16
*00:00 UTC (7:00 p.m. CDT, September 15) at Tropical Storm Gert weakens into a tropical depression inland about 40 mi (65 km) west of Bluefields, Nicaragua.
September 17
*Just after 12:00 UTC (7:00 a.m. CDT) at Tropical Depression Gert emerges over the Gulf of Honduras.
*18:00 UTC (1:00 p.m. CDT) at Tropical Depression Gert restrengthens into a tropical storm about 85 mi (140 km) south-southeast of Belize City, Belize.
September 18
*00:00 UTC (7:00 p.m. CDT, September 17) at Tropical Storm Gert makes landfall near Belize City, Belize, with sustained winds of 40 mph and a barometric pressure of .
*12:00 UTC (7:00 a.m. CDT) at Tropical Storm Gert weakens into a tropical depression inland over the Yucatán Peninsula.
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at A tropical depression forms from an interaction between a tropical wave and an upper-level low pressure area about 425 mi (685 km) south-southeast of Bermuda.
*Just after 18:00 UTC (1:00 p.m. CDT) at Tropical Depression Gert emerges over the Bay of Campeche.
September 19
*06:00 UTC (1:00 a.m. CDT) at Tropical Depression Gert restrengthens into a tropical storm about 320 mi (520 km) east of Tuxpan, Veracruz.
September 20
*06:00 UTC (1:00 a.m. CDT) at Tropical Storm Gert strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 155 mi (250 km) east of Tuxpan, Veracruz.
*06:00 UTC (2:00 a.m. AST) at The tropical depression that had formed well to the south-southeast of Bermuda 36 hours prior strengthens into Tropical Storm Harvey about 340 mi (545 km) east of the archipelago.
*18:00 UTC (1:00 p.m. CDT) at Hurricane Gert strengthens to Category 2 intensity about 35 mi (55 km) northeast of Tuxpan, Veracruz; it simultaneously reaches maximum sustained winds of 100 mph (155 km/h) and a minimum barometric pressure of .
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Harvey strengthens into a Category 1 hurricane about 595 mi (955 km) east-northeast of Bermuda; it simultaneously reaches maximum sustained winds of 75 mph (120 km/h) and a minimum barometric pressure of .
*21:00 UTC (4:00 p.m. CDT) at Hurricane Gert makes landfall near Tuxpan, Veracruz, at its peak intensity.
September 21
*00:00 UTC (7:00 p.m. CDT, September 20) at Hurricane Gert weakens to Category 1 intensity inland about 60 mi (95 km) west of Tuxpan, Veracruz.
*00:00 UTC (8:00 p.m. AST, September 20) at Hurricane Harvey weakens into a tropical storm about 790 mi (1,270 km) east-northeast of Bermuda.
*06:00 UTC (1:00 a.m. CDT) at Hurricane Gert weakens into a tropical storm inland about 180 mi (285 km) west of Tuxpan, Veracruz.
*12:00 UTC (7:00 a.m. CDT) at Tropical Storm Gert weakens into a tropical depression inland about 330 mi (530 km) west of Tuxpan, Veracruz.
*18:00 UTC (1:00 p.m. CDT) at Tropical Depression Gert is redesignated as Tropical Depression  as it approaches the Pacific coast of Mexico; it crosses into the Eastern Pacific basin shortly thereafter.
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at Tropical Storm Harvey transitions into an extratropical cyclone about 1,530 mi (2,465 km) northeast of Bermuda.
September 29
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at Tropical Depression Ten forms about 185 mi (295 km) south-southeast of Bermuda; it simultaneously reaches peak winds of 35 mph (55 km/h).
September 30
*12:00 UTC (8:00 a.m. AST) at Tropical Depression Ten reaches a minimum barometric pressure of  about 315 mi (510 km) north of Bermuda.
*18:00 UTC (2:00 p.m. AST) at Tropical Depression Ten is last noted as a tropical cyclone about 525 mi (845 km) north-northeast of Bermuda; it merges with a cold front six hours later, marking its dissipation.
October
*No tropical cyclones were active in October.
November
*No tropical cyclones were active in November.
November 30
*The 1993 Atlantic hurricane season officially ends.
Notes
See also
*Timeline of the 1993 Pacific hurricane season
*List of Atlantic hurricanes
*Atlantic hurricane season
*Tropical cyclones in 1993
References
External links
*The National Hurricane Center's [https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1993/ storm wallet for the 1993 Atlantic hurricane season]
